p: This study predicted the potential habitats for L. muta japonica under current and future climates at the territory scale (i.e. 300 m × 300 m, 0.09 km 2) by developing a model that considered the structure of the alpine ecosystem through incorporating spatial hierarchy on various environmental factors. Predicted current potential habitat was consistent with the current observed distribution of L. muta japonica territories, indicating that alpine vegetation communities, such as the P. pumila, snowbed grassland, and fellfield communities, are essential for L. muta japonica. Our findings are quantitatively consistent with previous studies on the ecology of L. muta japonica in Japan [ 49– 51].
